Dr. Hugh Dryden Joins
Honorary Service Frat
Dr. Hugh L. Dryden, Deputy
Administrator of the Aeronautics
and Space Administration, and
Mr. Rignal Baldwin, President
of the University's Alumni Association will be initiated into the
Johns Hopkins University chapter of Omicron Delta Kappa at
ceremonies Sunday at 12:00 noon
in Levering Hall on the Homewood Campus, it was announced
today by A. Zorel Paritzky, ODK
President.
Omicron Delta Kappa is a national leadership society which
elects students outstanding in
scholarship, athletics, campus
publications, the arts and student government to membership.
Following the initiation, the society will hold a dinner with Dr.
Dryden as guest speaker.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 10, 1961

Dr. Dryden, a native of Pocomoke City, Maryland, received
both his A.B. degree (1916) and
his Ph.D. (1919) from the University. He was associated for
many years with the National
Bureau of Standards, and was
Director of the National Advisory
Committee for Aerospace from
1947 to 1958, when he was appointed to his present position.
He is a member of the National Academy of Sciences, the
American Physical Society and
Phi Beta Kappa. He has re-

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 10, 1963

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE THREE

Brubeck Wails At'Center'
Past Grads Convene Ferguson, 'Hot Nuts'Star
For Festive Weekend At Big Dance Tomorrow
Alumni Homecoming for 1963
will be held Friday evening
through Sunday this weekend on
the Homewood Campus. More
than 1000 of the University's
almuni are expected to take part
in Homecoming activities, which
include luncheons, class dinners,
lectures, sports events, a parade
and a concert.
Alumni will register at the
University beginning at 9:00
A.M. Saturday in Levering Hall.
At 10:00 three lectures will be
available for the graduates and
their families: Dr. Phoebe B.
Stanton, Assistant Professor of
Art, will give a talk entitled
"Modern Architecture—Its Forms
and Their Meaning Today;" Dr.
Don C. Allen, Professor of English Literature, will present a
talk entitled "Literature and The
Fear of Comets:" and Dr. Douglas Warner, Jr., Research Associate at the University's Carlyle
Barton Laboratory, will present
a talk entitled "The Laser: Facts
and Fantasies."

Buffet Luncheon
After the lectures, a buffet
luncheon will be held at 11:30
at the Homewood Gymnasium
for all alumni, followed by the
Parade of the Classes and the
Float Parade at Homewood Field
at 1:15. Later in the afternoon,
alumni will attend the HopkinsNavy Lacrosse game, which will
be followed by open houses at
the fourteen Hopkins fraternities
and class dinners that evening.
Before the lacrosse game,
graduates of the class of 1913
will be presented 50-year alumni
medallions by the Alumni Association of the University.

Brunch Planned
At noon Sunday the classes of
1923, 1933 and 1938 will have a
"brunch," and at 8:30 Sunday
evening the Johns Hopkins Glee
Club and Orchestra will present
a special concert in Shriver Hall.

HARRISON L. WENT=

By TOM CARPENTER
The Cotillion Board and YMCA open their $12,500
show with a concert at the Civic Center tonight. Tickets
to the concert can be bought at the "Y" office; tickets to
the dance are on sale in the Dormitory Cafeteria.
The cost of entertainment alone, including Dave Brubeck, the Rooftop Singers, Maynard Ferguson, and the
Hot Nuts is $7,200 of the grand total. The board is optimistic with some tickets still available.
Brubeck and the Rooftop Singers will play at the Civic
center at 8:00 tonight. The world famous Quartet includes
its leader at the piano, Paul Desmond on the alto sax, Gene
Wright on the bass, and Joe Morello at his drums.
Rush To Fame
The Rooftop Singers who just rushed to fame with
their "Walk Right In" and "Tom Cat" are led by guitarist
and banjoist Eric Darling. Lynne Taylor and Bill Svanoe,
the other two members of the group are newcomers to the
world of recording but are by no means amateurs. Miss
Taylor, who sang 28 weeks straight at the Village Vanguard, was with the Benny Goodman Band for a year and
has made numerous radio and television appearances.
Bill Svanoe has played the guitar for seven years in
his travels and work across two continents. He is a graduate of Oberlin and the University of Minnesota.
Party Set
Following the Civic Center Concert the Cotillion
board has arranged a Block party in the Dorm Quad, featuring the music of the J Birds and for which the individual dorms will supply set ups. The party should last from

When all of you go to Europe during your summer vacation,
you will certainly want to visit Spain, where the tall coni grows,
The first thing you will notice upon entering Spain is the
absence of sibilants. In Spain "s" is pronounced "th" and
thereby hangs a tale. Until the reign of Philip IV—or Guy
Fawkes, as he was sometimes called—Spaniards said "s" just
like everybody else. Philip IV, however, lisped, and Spaniards,
having an ingrained sense of propriety and not wishing to embarrass their monarch, decided that everybody should lisp. This
did indeed put Philip IV very Much at his ease, but in the end
it turned out to be a very bad thing for Spain. It wrecked the
sassafras industry —Spain's principal source of revenue—and
reduced the nation to a second-class power.

As a result, Spaniards were all forced to turn to bull fighting
in order to keep body and soul together. Today, wherever you
go in Spain—in Madrid, in Barcelona, in Toledo, in Cleveland
—you will see bulls being fought. For many years the bulls
have sought to arbitrate this long-standing dispute, but the
Spaniards, a proud people who use nothing but Castile soap,
have rejected all overtures.
It is therefore necessary for me to explain bull fighting to
anyone who is going to Spain. It is also necessary for me to
say a few words about Marlboro Cigarettes because they pay
me for writing this column, and they are inclined to pout if I
ignore their product. In truth, it is no chore for me to sing the
praises of Marlboro Cigarettes, for I am one who fairly swoon...,
with delight when I come upon a cigarette which gives you the
full, rich taste of good tobaccos plus the pure white Selectrate
filter, and Marlboro is the only smoke I have found that fulfills
both requirements. Oh, what a piece of work is Marlboro! The
flavor reaches you without stint or diminution. You, even as I,
will find these statements to be happily true when once you
light a Marlboro. Marlboros come to you in soft pack or FlipTop box, and are made only by the makers of Marlboro.
But I digress. Let us return to bull fighting. Bulls are by
nature bellicose creatures who will keep fighting till the cows
come home. Then they like to put on pipe and slippers and
listen to the "Farm and Home Hour." However, the Spaniards
will not allow the bulls any surcease. They keep attacking the
bull and making veronicas—a corn meal pancake filled with
ground meat. Bulls, being vegetarians, reject the veronica'
and then, believe you me, the fur starts to fly!
To be perfectly honest, many Spaniards have grown weary
of this incessant struggle and have left their homeland. Columbus, for example, took off in three little ships—the Patti,
the Maxene, and the Laverne—and discovered Ohio. Magellan
later discovered Columbus. Balboa also sailed to the New
World, but he was silent on a peak in Darien, so it is difficult
to know what he discovered.
Well sir, I guess that's all you need to know about Spain.
So now, DA the setting sun casts its rosy fingers over El Greco,
let us take our reluctant leave of Spain—or Perfidious Albion,
as it is jocularly called. Aloha,Spain or Perfidious Albion,aloha!

Self Liberation
The task of liberation is one
of self liberation. It is not a
question of whether there is a
truth or not but of whether
there is an appetite for truth.
Modern man has no truth, not
because there is no truth, but
because he doesn't want any
truth. The indifference of those
who pretend to have the answer,
the fear of discovery of those
who haven't the answer, are the
obstacles in the path. The fortunate are not those who because
of an accident of birth have
truth dropped in their lap. The
fortunate are those who have the
opportunity to make a conscious
discovery.

and Space Administration, and

Brubeck Wails At'Center'
Past Grads Convene Ferguson, 'Hot Nuts'Star
For Festive Weekend At Big Dance Tomorrow
Alumni Homecoming for 1963
will be held Friday evening
through Sunday this weekend on
the Homewood Campus. More
than 1000 of the University's
almuni are expected to take part
in Homecoming activities, which
include luncheons, class dinners,
lectures, sports events, a parade
and a concert.
Alumni will register at the
University beginning at 9:00
A.M. Saturday in Levering Hall.
At 10:00 three lectures will be
available for the graduates and
their families: Dr. Phoebe B.
Stanton, Assistant Professor of
Art, will give a talk entitled
"Modern Architecture—Its Forms
and Their Meaning Today;" Dr.
Don C. Allen, Professor of English Literature, will present a
talk entitled "Literature and The
Fear of Comets:" and Dr. Douglas Warner, Jr., Research Associate at the University's Carlyle
Barton Laboratory, will present
a talk entitled "The Laser: Facts
and Fantasies."

Buffet Luncheon
After the lectures, a buffet
luncheon will be held at 11:30
at the Homewood Gymnasium
for all alumni, followed by the
Parade of the Classes and the
Float Parade at Homewood Field
at 1:15. Later in the afternoon,
alumni will attend the HopkinsNavy Lacrosse game, which will
be followed by open houses at
the fourteen Hopkins fraternities
and class dinners that evening.
Before the lacrosse game,
graduates of the class of 1913
will be presented 50-year alumni
medallions by the Alumni Association of the University.

Brunch Planned
At noon Sunday the classes of
1923, 1933 and 1938 will have a
"brunch," and at 8:30 Sunday
evening the Johns Hopkins Glee
Club and Orchestra will present
a special concert in Shriver Hall.

By TOM CARPENTER
The Cotillion Board and YMCA open their $12,500
show with a concert at the Civic Center tonight. Tickets
to the concert can be bought at the "Y" office; tickets to
the dance are on sale in the Dormitory Cafeteria.
The cost of entertainment alone, including Dave Brubeck, the Rooftop Singers, Maynard Ferguson, and the
Hot Nuts is $7,200 of the grand total. The board is optimistic with some tickets still available.
Brubeck and the Rooftop Singers will play at the Civic
center at 8:00 tonight. The world famous Quartet includes
its leader at the piano, Paul Desmond on the alto sax, Gene
Wright on the bass, and Joe Morello at his drums.
Rush To Fame
The Rooftop Singers who just rushed to fame with
their "Walk Right In" and "Tom Cat" are led by guitarist
and banjoist Eric Darling. Lynne Taylor and Bill Svanoe,
the other two members of the group are newcomers to the
world of recording but are by no means amateurs. Miss
Taylor, who sang 28 weeks straight at the Village Vanguard, was with the Benny Goodman Band for a year and
has made numerous radio and television appearances.
Bill Svanoe has played the guitar for seven years in
his travels and work across two continents. He is a graduate of Oberlin and the University of Minnesota.
Party Set

board has arranged a Block party in the Dorm Quad, featuring the music of the J Birds and for which the individual dorms will supply set ups. The party should last from

When all of you go to Europe during your summer vacation,
you will certainly want to visit Spain, where the tall coni grows,
The first thing you will notice upon entering Spain is the
absence of sibilants. In Spain "s" is pronounced "th" and
thereby hangs a tale. Until the reign of Philip IV—or Guy
Fawkes, as he was sometimes called—Spaniards said "s" just
like everybody else. Philip IV, however, lisped, and Spaniards,
having an ingrained sense of propriety and not wishing to embarrass their monarch, decided that everybody should lisp. This
did indeed put Philip IV very Much at his ease, but in the end
it turned out to be a very bad thing for Spain. It wrecked the
sassafras industry —Spain's principal source of revenue—and
reduced the nation to a second-class power.

As a result, Spaniards were all forced to turn to bull fighting
in order to keep body and soul together. Today, wherever you
go in Spain—in Madrid, in Barcelona, in Toledo, in Cleveland
—you will see bulls being fought. For many years the bulls
have sought to arbitrate this long-standing dispute, but the
Spaniards, a proud people who use nothing but Castile soap,
have rejected all overtures.
It is therefore necessary for me to explain bull fighting to
anyone who is going to Spain. It is also necessary for me to
say a few words about Marlboro Cigarettes because they pay
me for writing this column, and they are inclined to pout if I
ignore their product. In truth, it is no chore for me to sing the
praises of Marlboro Cigarettes, for I am one who fairly swoon...,
with delight when I come upon a cigarette which gives you the
full, rich taste of good tobaccos plus the pure white Selectrate
filter, and Marlboro is the only smoke I have found that fulfills
both requirements. Oh, what a piece of work is Marlboro! The
flavor reaches you without stint or diminution. You, even as I,
will find these statements to be happily true when once you
light a Marlboro. Marlboros come to you in soft pack or FlipTop box, and are made only by the makers of Marlboro.
But I digress. Let us return to bull fighting. Bulls are by
nature bellicose creatures who will keep fighting till the cows
come home. Then they like to put on pipe and slippers and
listen to the "Farm and Home Hour." However, the Spaniards
will not allow the bulls any surcease. They keep attacking the
bull and making veronicas—a corn meal pancake filled with
ground meat. Bulls, being vegetarians, reject the veronica'
and then, believe you me, the fur starts to fly!
To be perfectly honest, many Spaniards have grown weary
of this incessant struggle and have left their homeland. Columbus, for example, took off in three little ships—the Patti,
the Maxene, and the Laverne—and discovered Ohio. Magellan
later discovered Columbus. Balboa also sailed to the New
World, but he was silent on a peak in Darien, so it is difficult
to know what he discovered.
Well sir, I guess that's all you need to know about Spain.
So now, DA the setting sun casts its rosy fingers over El Greco,
let us take our reluctant leave of Spain—or Perfidious Albion,
as it is jocularly called. Aloha,Spain or Perfidious Albion,aloha!

Self Liberation
The task of liberation is one
of self liberation. It is not a
question of whether there is a
truth or not but of whether
there is an appetite for truth.
Modern man has no truth, not
because there is no truth, but
because he doesn't want any
truth. The indifference of those
who pretend to have the answer,
the fear of discovery of those
who haven't the answer, are the
obstacles in the path. The fortunate are not those who because
of an accident of birth have
truth dropped in their lap. The
fortunate are those who have the
opportunity to make a conscious
discovery.

The varsity lacrosse team plans
to upset both Navy and the oddsmakers
tomorrow
afternoon
when they take on undefeated
Navy (6-0) team at Homewood
Field. Coach Bob Scott's Jays
take a 6-1 slate into the game.
The game promises to be one
of the best of the season. Both
teams are solid at all positions,
and both have been pointing for
this game all season. The Tars
are trying for their second consecutive undefeated season. The
Jays want to stop Navy and reverse their 16-11 loss of a year
ago.
Navy has skill, depth, and
speed, no more than any other
great team. Coach Bill Bilderback alternates two top-ranked
attack units. George Tracy, Arnold Glassner, Dud Hendrick,
Ted Willandt, Bill Fromme, and
Brian Lantier all have good
moves and good shots.

OMAN LANTIER

hands, dodges well, and feeds
well.
